s.text: The cultures were then visualized using a Nikon Diaphot fluorescent microscope with a fluorescein filter and a 4x or 10x objective.
The sections were then dehydrated by immersion in 70% ethanol (3 immersions, 6 minutes each) and then transferred to 95% ethanol for 6 minutes.
The sections were then dehydrated by immersion in 70% ethanol (3 immersions, 6 minutes each) and then transferred to 95% ethanol for 6 minutes.
The sections were then dehydrated by immersion in 70% ethanol (3 immersions, 6 minutes each) and then transferred to 95% ethanol for 6 minutes.
Neurite length was assessed by tracing the neurite using the straight-line tool in NIH Image.
Neurite orientation was defined as the angle of the line traced over the neurite.
The spatial extent of the tract was marked by tracing around the perimeter of the visible tract using the polygon tool.
Control sections were treated for the same length of time at the same temperature with Ham's F12 medium rather than formalin.
Control sections were treated for the same length of time at the same temperature with Ham's F12 medium rather than formalin.
Therefore, taken together, the effects of fixation and polyornithine suggest that haptotactic cues are insufficient to guide parallel neurite growth.
These data suggest that the orienting influence of white matter geometry on neurite outgrowth involves myelin and, possibly, its associated neurite-growth inhibitory activity.

For example, in the spinal cord, where successful regeneration ultimately depends on axon extension in an appropriate direction over long distances, factors that promote parallel axonal growth, and discourage non-parallel growth, should enhance long-distance regeneration.

For example, in the spinal cord, where successful regeneration ultimately depends on axon extension in an appropriate direction over long distances, factors that promote parallel axonal growth, and discourage non-parallel growth, should enhance long-distance regeneration.

For example, in the spinal cord, where successful regeneration ultimately depends on axon extension in an appropriate direction over long distances, factors that promote parallel axonal growth, and discourage non-parallel growth, should enhance long-distance regeneration.
The term "inhibitor" refers to the effects of myelin on neurites in studies that did not consider its normal geometric organization within white matter.
, companion paper http://www.biomedcentral.com/1471-2202/2/8).
In order to deactivate biochemical guidance cues while preserving haptotactic cues that may guide parallel neurite growth, brain sections were fixed prior to use as substrata for cultured neurons.
In order to deactivate biochemical guidance cues while preserving haptotactic cues that may guide parallel neurite growth, brain sections were fixed prior to use as substrata for cultured neurons.
In order to deactivate biochemical guidance cues while preserving haptotactic cues that may guide parallel neurite growth, brain sections were fixed prior to use as substrata for cultured neurons.
The term "inhibitor" refers to the effects of myelin on neurites in studies that did not consider its normal geometric organization within white matter.
Since the parallel growth constraint may be due to the combined action of multiple inhibitors, treatments that are known to attenuate the overall inhibitory properties of myelin were selected.
Since the parallel growth constraint may be due to the combined action of multiple inhibitors, treatments that are known to attenuate the overall inhibitory properties of myelin were selected.
